messages.subject: Re: Mysterious Do-gooder
messages.msgSnippet: Indeed.. Those Zulu yari are just as likely to be modern day repros as the Chinese fakes on ebay though :-) Pity they are all mumei though. Traditional weapons
messages.messageBody:
Indeed..

Those Zulu yari are just as likely to be modern day repros as the
Chinese fakes on ebay though :-)
Pity they are all mumei though. Traditional weapons are a problem.
When carried at political rallies, the cops daren't try and take them
away for fear they are accused of disrespecting cultural items that
aren't weapons..just symbols.
I am sure there are parallels in the Japanese art world, where you
have to ignore the original status of items as weapons, and see them
in a new light as symbols of history and art.

Brian

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "bungotakadasword"
<MuramasaIII@...> wrote:
>
> In a message dated 2/23/2007 12:06:05 P.M. Central Standard Time,
> sigp210@... writes:
> Here in South Africa we don't need any permits or permissions to own
> any edged weapons.
>
>
> I can imagine it's sort of difficult to take away Shaka Zulu's ASSEGAI
>
>
> milt
>

any edged weapons.


I can imagine it's sort of difficult to take away Shaka Zulu's ASSEGAI

messages.subject: Re: Mysterious Do-gooder
messages.msgSnippet: I agree completely. It is all about the level of force needed to protect ones life from deadly harm. I too, am in law enforcment; I work as a corrections
messages.messageBody:
I agree completely. It is all about the 'level of force' needed to
protect ones life from deadly harm. I too, am in law enforcment; I
work as a corrections deputy. The levels of force are studied yearly
in order to keep certification.

But, I know of no thief who doesn't carry at least a screw driver and
when used properly, can be a deadly weapon. So rather than get sued
for maiming him (her) for life, I will prove beyond a reasonable
doubt, that the thief came after me to do bodily harm and thats why I
killed him.

I rest my case.

Elliott

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "sigp210" <sigp210@...> wrote:
>
> Here in South Africa we don't need any permits or permissions to own
> any edged weapons.
> Self defence is allowed, and any available weapon would be ok, as
long
> as there was serious risk to life.
> Lethal force in defence of property is not encouraged, and can lead
to
> charges. The weapon is irrellevant, be it one of my wakizashi or my
Glock.
>
> Brian
>
> --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Elliott" <elliott@> wrote:
> >
> > If your defending your family and/or home against any intruder,
make
> > sure you 'kill' him. It is the only way to win in court - self
> > defense. I have both a sword and a Glock for just this purpose.
No
> > one will break into my home and live to tell about it.
> >
> >
>

messages.subject: Re: Mysterious Do-gooder
messages.msgSnippet: Here in South Africa we don t need any permits or permissions to own any edged weapons. Self defence is allowed, and any available weapon would be ok, as long
messages.messageBody:
Here in South Africa we don't need any permits or permissions to own
any edged weapons.
Self defence is allowed, and any available weapon would be ok, as long
as there was serious risk to life.
Lethal force in defence of property is not encouraged, and can lead to
charges. The weapon is irrellevant, be it one of my wakizashi or my Glock.

Brian

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Elliott" <elliott@...> wrote:
>
> If your defending your family and/or home against any intruder, make
> sure you 'kill' him. It is the only way to win in court - self
> defense. I have both a sword and a Glock for just this purpose. No
> one will break into my home and live to tell about it.
>
>

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Mysterious Do-gooder
messages.msgSnippet: Everyone,                   Just thought I d share this with you.  This is how things go down in Canada.  I ve copied and pasted the answer
messages.messageBody:
Everyone,
                  Just thought I'd share this with you.  This is how things
go down in Canada.  I've copied and pasted the answer from my RCMP friend.
 
"So on to the legal question...in Canada you can use as much force as is
necessary to defend yourself and others but no more. In order words, you
must be able to justify the force you used. If burglar enters your home and
you surprise him (or her in a politically correct world) with sword in hand
and burglar flees...your done, the defence is complete. If, while burglar is
in the process of getting his/her butt out of your house you use your latest
iaido move to slice a pound of flesh off, you are in serious s**t.
Alternately, if burglar is armed and means to kill you for your meager
belongings and you use your best iaido move to slice a pound of flesh off,
then it becomes your word against his/hers. The most important
statement...you have to justify the force you used. The weapon you use is
irrelevant. You will have to explain why you used what you did and justify
it to satisfy a judge in court. THEN...there's the whole civil side of the
law. If, as a result of the pound of flesh you sliced off, burglar can no
longer function in society, can't hold a job and support him or herself
(even if that job is burglary) you might get your butt sued and will have to
support said burglar for a long time. In Canada it's all a matter of
justification of the force used."

Mark

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Mark Jaillet
Sent: Thursday, February 22, 2007 3:10 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Mysterious Do-gooder



Am I the only one out here who thinks that defending family and home with
any means necessary against a burglar "inside" your own home is O.K.? 
 
Bob,  do you know if there was prejudice against the sword itself or would
the home owner still have gone to jail if he stabbed the burglar with...lets
say a salad fork?
 
Here's a question for everyone out there in Nihonto land,  can you briefly
tell me how your individual countries feel about "swords" in general?   I
live in Canada and we have major restrictions when it comes to fire arms.  I
will ask an RCMP friend of mine what would happen to me if I defended myself
inside my home with my katana against a burglar and I'll let you all know.
 
Mark
 

-----Original Message-----
From: HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com
[mailto: HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com]On
Behalf Of bob griffis
Sent: Thursday, February 22, 2007 2:53 PM
To: HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Mysterious Do-gooder

The laws in England have changed much in the last few years. For
example, a gent was arrested, convicted and imprisoned for defending
himself in his own home using a sword against an unarmed burglar who had
broken into his house. I don't know specifically if possession of a
bladed weapon is a problem, but any aggressive or defense use likely is
a problem.

Bob Elder wrote:
>
> Is possession of a cutting sword in England illegal? I
> am going there to teach cutting seminars at 3 dojos.
> Bob Elder
>
> > Mark,
> >
> > yeah, except that the British authorities are
> > probably looking for the
> > guy so he can be arrested for weapons violations..--.
> >
> > rkg
> > (Richard George)
> >
> > Mark Jaillet wrote:
> >
> > >Finally, I positive modern day story involving a
> > sword. How refreshing!
> > >
> > >Mark
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >
> >
> >
>
>

--

messages.subject: Re: Mysterious Do-gooder
messages.msgSnippet: If your defending your family and/or home against any intruder, make sure you kill him. It is the only way to win in court - self defense. I have both a
messages.messageBody:
If your defending your family and/or home against any intruder, make
sure you 'kill' him. It is the only way to win in court - self
defense. I have both a sword and a Glock for just this purpose. No
one will break into my home and live to tell about it.

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Mysterious Do-gooder
messages.msgSnippet: Am I the only one out here who thinks that defending family and home with any means necessary against a burglar inside your own home is O.K.?    Bob,  do
messages.messageBody:
Am I the only one out here who thinks that defending family and home with
any means necessary against a burglar "inside" your own home is O.K.? 
 
Bob,  do you know if there was prejudice against the sword itself or would
the home owner still have gone to jail if he stabbed the burglar with...lets
say a salad fork?
 
Here's a question for everyone out there in Nihonto land,  can you briefly
tell me how your individual countries feel about "swords" in general?   I
live in Canada and we have major restrictions when it comes to fire arms.  I
will ask an RCMP friend of mine what would happen to me if I defended myself
inside my home with my katana against a burglar and I'll let you all know.
 
Mark
 

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of bob griffis
Sent: Thursday, February 22, 2007 2:53 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Mysterious Do-gooder



The laws in England have changed much in the last few years. For
example, a gent was arrested, convicted and imprisoned for defending
himself in his own home using a sword against an unarmed burglar who had
broken into his house. I don't know specifically if possession of a
bladed weapon is a problem, but any aggressive or defense use likely is
a problem.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Mysterious Do-gooder
messages.msgSnippet: The laws in England have changed much in the last few years.  For example, a gent was arrested, convicted and imprisoned for defending himself in his own home
messages.messageBody:
The laws in England have changed much in the last few years. For
example, a gent was arrested, convicted and imprisoned for defending
himself in his own home using a sword against an unarmed burglar who had
broken into his house. I don't know specifically if possession of a
bladed weapon is a problem, but any aggressive or defense use likely is
a problem.

Bob Elder wrote:
>
> Is possession of a cutting sword in England illegal? I
> am going there to teach cutting seminars at 3 dojos.
> Bob Elder
>
> > Mark,
> >
> > yeah, except that the British authorities are
> > probably looking for the
> > guy so he can be arrested for weapons violations...
> >
> > rkg
> > (Richard George)
> >
> > Mark Jaillet wrote:
> >
> > >Finally, I positive modern day story involving a
> > sword. How refreshing!
> > >
> > >Mark
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >
> >
> >
>
>

--
Robert Griffis
